message: Is there any free tool out there, possibly hosted on the cloud, where we can have some kind of gannt chart... track this needs to be done on this date.. etc..etc and many more features
I think tracker is not free anymore, though.
I am coordinating a project of 3 people, so I need this tool to manage and organize this better
I usually use redmine or pivotal tracker for this.
+1 Pivotal Tracker
we use a mix of Basecamp and Interstate
neither do gannt charts but they're still great for project management/dev

Interesting that this comes up. Means there is a need for the startup that I'm in the midst of.  Currently, there is a cloud product in the works which will aim at small to mid-sized development teams with purchasable modules. GitHub integration & bug tracking would be included along with gannt charts and calenders. A minimalistic Todo will be implemented as well.

Sadly, I don't imagine there will be a useable project until at least 2 months out.

In the meantime, there is Basecamp & Planbox that might bit your needs.
I think Redmine fits your needs. http://www.redmine.org/
+1 pivotal tracker
definitely +1 for pivotal tracker (it's got a solid SaaS pricing model, free to start $7 for 3 collaborators, 60 day free trial).

The new Codebase is looking spiffy: http://codebasehq.com/v4 

I, for one, can't wait to try it… :)
we use redmine

Are any of you guys Taskforce users? (http://www.taskforceapp.com) We'd love to hear your thoughts on integrating with existing project management and dev tools, since so much of those kinds of tasks and assignments originate in your inbox.
what do you people think of JIRA?
My JIRA experience is probably colored by the nature of the company using it, though.
I use Jira day-to-day - not by choice though. I've not had enough experience with any alternatives, but I'm planning on using Pivotal Tracker for personal stuff

I've used basecamp, jira, mantis, redmine, trac, unfuddle and pivotal tracker in various capacities.   Although those range from task management to bug tracking to a mix.  Probably would rank them (best to worst):  Unfuddle, mantis, basecamp, redmine, trac, jira.
I just noticed that GMail actually already has in-app task management, but it's nowhere near as easy or convenient to use as Taskforce. I'll be plugging it to the guys at work!
I never knew Taskforce existed. I just installed it, and I'm already pretty sure it's gonna be a big part of my project management flow now @courtland
+1 for pivotaltracker, it is so beautiful compared to Rallydev I had to use at work
PivotalTracker is excellent. I use Workflowy to keep track of personal todos.
redmine in ruby is good but it really needs some power. So it's not free 'cause of the hosting fees
@collypops Very cool, would love to hear your suggestions!
Emacs of a txt file. Dropbox. Instant cappucinos. Regular sex. CMake. My own scripts for boilerplate.
Do you guys use any tools to track your time (instead of just tasks)? I notice my attention is usually torn between projects so I've been searching for something to manage my time better
I'm currently trying out www.freedcamp.com . It's simple, the only thing I really mis is a bug-tracker. But they do have a nice todo-list that can be used for this.
@johnthedebs We use a tool we built internally based on the Pomodoro Technique: pomodoroplanner.com.

We use Interstate (www.interstateapp.com) for high level features and Pivotal Tracker for individual stories. It's a nice combination that helps developers and the rest of the business know what's going on.

I used redmine (this was about 12 months ago, it may be greatly improved by now) recently and while the system was great, it kicked the crap out of my server. For what, outwardly is a pretty straight forward system, it needs a lot of juice. For something as important as project management I'd go for a service like pivotal tracker, or goplan. Depending on your needs you may need to compromise on the 'free' part.
have used GoPlan with some success http://goplanapp.com/

A pretty simple time tracking app for mac is timeEdition and I believe its free. One of my favorite function is that I can export the records to something like a google doc to share with others. Check it out at http://www.timeedition.com. The best part is that its Free.
+1 Pivotal Tracker--even if it's no longer free
Pivotal Tracker!!!
clockingit.com is what I am using for a personal project. Free, hosted online, can be installed on your own server, does gantt charts, reports and more.
http://www.clockingit.com
